results.body: Lars Nootbaar, a high-energy outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals, was the first player born outside Japan to play for its national team. He put on a show.
results.title: Grinding His Way to International Stardom

results.body: The Mets have had a poor start to their season, but on the day their home opener is scheduled, fans are still believing.
results.title: The New York Mets: Fair or Foul Weather Ahead?

results.body: Why the new baseball season is somewhat shocking.
results.title: Major League Baseball Has Unleashed a Faster, Freer Version of Itself. You’ll Need to Pay Attention.

results.body: Readers react to the mass shooting in Nashville. Also: Cheaper baseball games; listening to adversaries; Daniel Ellsberg’s inspiration to many.
results.title: Why Does Our Society Produce So Many Mass Murderers?

results.body: A roster that boasts 37 All-Star selections has one of Major League Baseball’s highest payrolls. It comes with loads of enthusiasm, and expectations to match.
results.title: Once a Scrappy Underdog, the Padres Adjust to Penthouse Life

results.body: In his first regular-season start since coming over from Japan, Kodai Senga baffled the Marlins with his signature pitch: the ghost fork.
results.title: A Steep Learning Curve and a Steeper Forkball for Mets Rookie

results.body: A sport that wanted more action got its wish, but a series of major rule changes has some major leaguers struggling to keep up.
results.title: ‘I Felt Like I Was at Warp Speed’: Baseball Adapts to a New Era

results.body: The publisher of The New York Times received a Red Sox World Series ring after Boston’s historic triumph in 2004.
results.title: An Unlikely Champion

results.body: A five-year collective bargaining agreement was voted in by more than 99 percent of minor league players. Housing, meals and transportation are expected to improve.
results.title: Minor League Salaries Will Double Under New Deal

results.body: Opening day suggested how much difference a pitch clock can make.
results.title: See How Baseball’s New Rules Changed the Game
